{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3334870,"name":"Rishabh","username":"endorphin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/endorphin/{size}/238204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T02:02:12.402Z","cooked":"

During our San Antonio competition this weekend we had numerous issues with our beam break sensors mainly due to the wires being too small. In addition to this other teams have told us about their bad experiences with it. What alternatives do your teams use that would use a similar amount of space.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T02:02:12.402Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":227,"reads":507,"readers_count":506,"score":1256.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Rishabh","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53133,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5427 Design Lead | Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/1","custom_user_title":"5427 Design Lead | Drive Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3334893,"name":"Drew Tompkins","username":"DrewT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/drewt/{size}/174246_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T02:22:39.830Z","cooked":"

We have been using these Banner sensors that reflect against a retroreflective surface. They have worked well except for a few false positives. You need to make sure you have a large reflective area especially if it is on a moving part. We have also bought some of this same model from eBay and those have worked just as good but you milage may vary on eBay. QS18VN6LV Banner Engineering Corporation | Sensors, Transducers | DigiKey

We‚Äôve been having a pretty good experience with the DFRobot photoelectric switch. They have a super small form factor and go right into the RIO‚Äôs DIO.

dfrobot.com

5V IR Photoelectric Switch (4m)

This IR break beam sensor works up to 4m with a fast and stable response of 0.5ms. Power the sensor by a voltage of DC 5V. It can be used with Arduino in smart robot competitions.

Price: 11.9000 USD

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T03:08:57.831Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":470,"readers_count":469,"score":114.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Oliver","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.dfrobot.com/product-2644.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"5V IR Photoelectric Switch (4m) - DFRobot","clicks":85}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3729 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/3","custom_user_title":"3729 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335043,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T07:49:22.217Z","cooked":"

These IR Reflection Photoelectric Switches are cheap and easy to use.
https://www.amazon.com/HiLetgo-E18-D80NK-Infrared-Photoelectric-Avoidance/dp/B07VKR1GBJ/

You can adjust the sensitivity of the sensor, you get a simple digital output, it is easy to securely mount, you can easily adjust the sensor forward/back using the threaded portion, simplified wiring, and you don‚Äôt have to worry about making sure your beam brake elements are ‚Äúperfectly‚Äù in line with each other and won‚Äôt be knocked about.

you should even be able to wire these directly into your motor controller‚Äôs data port as a limit switch if you wanted to avoid wiring back to the RIO since they are an NPN/NO photoelectric sensor (floating output when not no object detected, and LOW output when object detected). Just make sure to disable the limit switch pins from actually stopping your motor output from going a given direction if that is not intended behavior.

I‚Äôve had several good experiences with Sharp brand beam break and distance sensors over the years, and no bad ones. These appear to be the same sensors they use in their copiers and printers and such, they‚Äôre quite inexpensive, and they just work. Pololu (www.polololu.com) sells a variety of them, and breakouts for easy soldering or connections by Dupont (PWM) connectors.

endorphin:

mainly due to the wires being too small

Hopefully not inspection issues?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T10:40:24.035Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":344,"readers_count":343,"score":93.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Nate Laverdure (he/him)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":4999,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Cynicism isn't wisdom"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/6","custom_user_title":"Cynicism isn't wisdom","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335076,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T12:15:40.933Z","cooked":"
ExploitSage:

These IR Reflection Photoelectric Switches are cheap and easy to use.
https://www.amazon.com/HiLetgo-E18-D80NK-Infrared-Photoelectric-Avoidance/dp/B07VKR1GBJ/

We switched from the adafruit breakbeam sensors to these. Only caveat is that these have inverse signals ‚Äì these go high when there‚Äôs something in the way, while the breakbeams are high when nothing is in the way. That‚Äôs a small code change.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T12:15:40.933Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":318,"readers_count":317,"score":83.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335085,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T13:05:19.810Z","cooked":"

E18-D80NK is the poor person‚Äôs Banner. The hiletgo versions plug right into the RoboRIO.

The banner sensors are more reliable if you can spare the money but I‚Äôve never had an issue with the E18-D80NK.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T13:05:19.810Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":284,"readers_count":283,"score":71.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335101,"name":"John Bottenberg","username":"John_Bottenberg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_bottenberg/{size}/224569_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T13:58:27.502Z","cooked":"

What are the exact issues with the Adafruit beam break sensor? My team used These ones at our first competition and encountered no issues other than the one match where they were dislodged because of improper mounting.

Anything in particular we should be concerned about? There‚Äôs a lot of bashing of the sensor in this thread but not much detailed discussion about its flaws. This is our first year using this sensor so we really want to anticipate any issues so that we can address them if they occur.

Is it possible that there are some suitable applications and some unsuitable applications for this sensor? We are using it inside our intake/shooter system to sense the note.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T13:58:27.502Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":244,"readers_count":243,"score":98.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.adafruit.com/product/2168","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : $5.95 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits","clicks":30}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714‚Üê4973‚Üê2930‚Üê3322‚Üê67"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/9","custom_user_title":"3142, 8706, 714‚Üê4973‚Üê2930‚Üê3322‚Üê67","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335110,"name":"Sean Smith","username":"s_smith6933","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T14:07:32.732Z","cooked":"

My team has used the Allen-Bradley RightSight line of photoelectric sensors for beam break very successfully for a few years. They are easy to use and connect to the DIO pins on the RoboRIO. Here is some information about them. We‚Äôve received many of them through FIRST Choice over the years. They are very robust and not cheap amazon garbage. We did have one fail this season, as it stopped giving consistent output results, but it appears to be 4+ years old and we just swapped it out with a new one. Other than that, they‚Äôve been dead reliable. Unfortunately, they may be a bit bigger than the Adafruit ones you‚Äôre using.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T14:11:21.063Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":72.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Sean Smith","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://literature.rockwellautomation.com/idc/groups/literature/documents/pp/42ef-pp002_-en-p.pdf","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":19},{"url":"https://firstchoicebyandymark.com/fc-ra-7322","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FCbyAM - Photoelectric Sensor, RightSight (42EF-D2MPAK-F4)","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56469,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPI '27"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/10","custom_user_title":"WPI '27","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335291,"name":"Rishabh","username":"endorphin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/endorphin/{size}/238204_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T19:34:52.277Z","cooked":"

The issue was that any form of connection that we used, whether it was Wagos (both full size and mini/can wagos) or soldering they would give us a spotty connection.

In our experience the wiring between the sensor and the Rio is incredible sketchy because of how small the output wires are. We also had one that became stuck in the always unblocked mode even when the ir transmitter was working and placed right in front of it.

E18-D80NK is the poor person‚Äôs Banner.

My mortal enemy. It‚Äôs my personal mission to speak out against them every time Anand recommends them. Industrial banner sensors have never failed us. They‚Äôre expensive, but they work every time, unlike the 4 E18-D80NK we threw out last year.

Too many ‚Äúlo‚Äù in the URL. Try these Pololu Digital Distance Sensor 15cm
I think there are 2 or 3 different sensors with jumpers that can be changed to vary the range. If you‚Äôve miscalculated or need a different range than the default for the one you bought all is not lost - just change the jumper. My team has used these exclusively for a few years to locate game pieces in the robot.

We have been using a LaserCAN and it has be working great. They are absolutely tiny and have great range without the need for anything on the other side of were you sensing.

We‚Äôre loving the LaserCan for break beam and distance checks. Quick to wire up, easy to mount, and easy to code for.

We used Adafruit break beams in years prior, and had a number of issues with light levels and reflective elements. We definitely wouldn‚Äôt go back.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2024-03-18T04:36:45.057Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":158,"readers_count":157,"score":46.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458928,"topic_slug":"alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/alternatives-to-adafruit-beam-break-sensors/458928/17","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3338382,"name":"Brady Starler","username":"Brady_S42","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brady_s42/{size}/203921_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-20T15:24:19.854Z","cooked":"

My team‚Äôs experience with LaserCAN has been pretty good so far, but we‚Äôre fairly new to photoelectric sensors. We‚Äôve been having problems with it shorting occasionally and it ended up being the pinout.

There are two ways to wire LaserCAN. If you‚Äôre using more than one device, it would be imperative that you wire the two in parallel. The live and ground will be soldered to their respective pads on the board, with one hi wire and one lo wire on their pads, same for the other pads on the other sides.

The other way is if you‚Äôre only using one device. When using one device, the pinout our team uses is dissimilar to the one shown above. Instead of using both sets of pads, we use only one: 1 live, 1 ground, 2 lo CAN, 2 hi CAN. The live and ground are soldered to their respective pads again, but this time, I used two sets of twisted CAN wire with the hi CAN of both soldered onto the hi CAN pad, with both lo CAN onto the lo CAN pad.

twistedCAN1500√ó1500 50.1 KB

Using this twisted pattern, you can isolate the two green wires from both to solder them onto the pads, along with the yellow wires onto their pad. This will require a total of six wires to make it work, so we decided to use an already cut encoder cable not only to extend the cable to our CAN chain at the belly pan, but also to indicate that these wires go to the LaserCAN.

If there are any problems with the LaserCAN shorting, resolder each connection on the pads, and maybe use hot glue to keep any whiskers or solder drip from going to different pads.

We use a PWFusion time of flight sensor that measures the distance to an object. These can be used in place of a beam break sensor by checking if the distance is under a certain value and work over CAN. These work well in all lighting conditions and communication is all over CAN. They are out of stock right now but they are worth keeping around. Playing With Fusion - CAN Bus Time of Flight Range, Distance, and Proximity Smart Sensor
